entry.title: SickOs: 1.1
entry.content:
Image: SickOs: 1.1

Nmap output:

There is an open proxy, we try internal network reconnaissance:

We found the Wolf CMS and to have easier access, we set the HTTP proxy in Firefox. After a little googling, we found this exploit, but it only uploads php shell and we can do this manually. To use this technique, we need credentials to log in via admin interface. One of our first guesses was admin/admin, so we upload the file with the following content for RCE:

As we can read in exploit, the uploaded files are available in public directory. Invoking a few commands:

Here we found the database user credentials:

Examining the MySQL database:

Nothing interesting here, there is only one user and we already know his password.

We noticed that the user www-data has shell access:

Next idea is to upload ssh authorization key and log in via ssh.

We created the directory for authorized_keys file:

To encode spaces:

To store public key:

We verify successful upload:

It does not work, the server is still asking password, even when we try to set more restricted permission:

We come back to this later. Trying different payload, we encode the following command and invoke via our backdoor, the second output is ascii encoded using Burp Encoder:

This is how we got the remote shell:

We connect to MySQL again, this time we noticed that there is user sickos with the same password as mysql root, that is john@123.

His shell uses the same password and we can easily escalate to uid 0.

Reading the auth.log, we also found out the reason why ssh did not worked:

Unfortunately our user could not change this permission.

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 4
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1.3 (#4)

Nmap output:

There is a member login on the http://192.168.80.154/index.php site, we try the following credentials (SQLi):

We logged into member site and after a few seconds found the local file inclusion vulnerability. Filtering the etc string could be easily evaded for displaying /etc/passwd:

smbmap output reveals:

Now we try to inject php backdoor. For this purpose, we use our session file. The file has a fixed location /var/lib/php5/sess_ with the appended session cookie name:

As we can see, the myusername session variable could be used to easily inject our code:

We need to login using these credentials:

Now we have a backdoor, that uses parameter cmd. Digging deeper, we use python to execute reverse shell:

Because the mysql instance is running as root user, we have a full access to the database. We dump it and use the credentials for ssh login, for example with the user john. The lshell is executed, but noticing his .lhistory file, bash could be directly executed too. Finally, we set the suid privileges for dash using mysql and obtain the root privileges:

Because the UDF exploitation is well known for sqlmap, we could solve the challenge also using this tool:

entry.title: ICEC.TF Writeup
entry.content:
ROT13

Cryptic Crypto

For substitution cipher: http://quipqiup.com/index.php

Statistics

Ryan Gooseling

SHARKNADO!

Farm Animals

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pigpen_cipher

RSA

Shocked!

Hackers in disguise

I have found the solution for the almost same challenge, more information abouth the vulnerability here.

Fermat

Barista

Similarly like in Hack.lu CTF 2014: Objection, we overwroted the getter function for is_admin:

Vulnerable line:

PyShell

Similar as here: https://hexplo.it/escaping-the-csawctf-python-sandbox/

Entropy

We have the python daemon, that uses only a few primes (they are stored in text file and keys are generated almost instantly).

In the challenge information is provided public key (N, e = 257) and encrypted data c, that we want to decrypt:

After fetching a few public keys, using information from the presentation and source, we want to find the common primes.

Because the 174530909087014... value is divisible by our public key, we were able to factor it and we got q = N / p.

Authorize

Time-delay injection in register field, using POST method:

To solve it quickly, we used sqlmap:

Elevate

Obviously, the flag.txt file is read, but from current working directory.

Solution:

Supernote

Exploitable code:

There is a race condition, we can create a symlink pointing to arbitrary file, then our data is stored here, finally the symlink is removed. The cron.README hints us to use python script for executing .task(s). Moreover cron needs permission for writing to our directory.

Because I was interested also what exactly is executing via cron, using the same technique, I did:

Wiki & The Furious

DOM Based XSS challenge. The vulnerable code:

The injected javascript code could be evaluated here:

Test URL:

We need to deliver the payload to admin:

After setting cookie to the value s:NO7VjJneMo5ArzEcrwTUXMIR2W9A05RU.Xg8/oyINQGJh09tP234WRlXFaE3NsBEeOHFRyN2FmCo, we was able to read the flag: flag_so_simple_yet_so_hard.

What

Simple RE challenge. There is a binary without source code, performing a several checks:

On our server:

CTF server:

Now we only need to jump to our shellcode

entry.title: Acid Server: 1
entry.content:
Image: Acid Server: 1

We received the IP address 192.168.80.158 for the vulnerable image. Nmap output for TCP scan:

We found the web server. There was a hex value as the last line of the index page:

Converting in python:

We downloaded the picture and found another hex string:

Googling this MD5 hash, we found out that it represents the value 63425:

After a few minutes of waiting, the UDP scan finished, but we found only NTP server listening:

Reading the page title (or dirb tool) reveals an interesting URL: http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/

We had no further access for /protected_page.php, but the first idea that we had was a referrer check. After verifying by spoofing this value:

Proceeding further, there are a few hints for sql injection, but nothing that we have tried worked: http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/hacked.php?id=33&add=Add+ID

Trying sqlmap or manual identification was without success, however Burp Suite Scanner revealed, that the parameter ID is vulnerable, when it’s sent in POST method:

Now we can use sqlmap and retrieve some useful information:

Because the hashes are salted SHA512, it was not reasonable to crack them. Instead, using google we found the hashes from test_user here:

We log in and proceed to the text step:

There was <!--0x5933566a4c6e4a34626e413d--> on the page, that means after hex/base64/rot13/reverse cake.php.

We identified LFI:

http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/cake.php shows also the http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/Magic_Box/ URL.

Dirb found http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/Magic_Box/proc, where we put our next focus.

We wanted to hack the server using /proc/self/environ technique, but the server was a recent ubuntu version and we found only reference to session variable file.

We gave up hacking via /proc, but dirb reveals another files:

Now we understand from the index page the sentence Fairy tails uses secret keys to open the magical doors.

Seems that we almost won, because RCE (OS Commanding) on http://192.168.80.158:33447/Challenge/Magic_Box/tails.php.

We realized after a few seconds, that there is no nc with executable property, no curl, no wget and no writable place in DocumentRoot on obvious place, we tried to store something to /var/www/html/. We could send anything over netcat, but using python reverse shell could be more efficient:

We are connected and now we need to escalate our privileges. We found:

The first file was suspicious, after copying to our server and simple analysis we found the following:

Finally, we use the string 1337hax0r as password:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Final Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Final0

We attach to the process as root to find the offset with stored EIP.

So EAX points at the beginning to the buffer and we are lucky, because there is also call eax in binary.

We use msfvenom to generate bind shell, port 2449, without newline characters and with uppercase encoding:

The lower case t at the beginning of the payload is used in order to find the payload’s absolute location in memory and obtain a position-independent shellcode, more here.

Because we can refer to this position also with the register eax, we can get rid of lower case character:

Exploit:

Protostar Final1

We don’t use spaces to find our format string to have more spaces left for exploit. Also, both username and login parameters are vulnerable, we use username to store shellcode and login for overwriting GOT entry for puts(). The line with timestamp is the entry from /var/log/syslog file.

We have 109 bytes for shellcode, not much but it should be sufficient.

In order to pass this challenge, we need to store the address 0x0804a220 to 0x0804a194. Our formatter.rb is the same script as in the protostar format challenges.

Exploitation process:

So, we have 0x08a1a2bd instead of 0x0804a220, let’s see the difference:

Substracting 157 from 2044, we got 1887 and that is the correct value, which we will use. Another try:

That’s correct, now we need to generate payload not longer than 109 bytes:

Protostar Final2

The vulnerability is in this part of the source:

It expects message with the content ..../..ROOT.../next, look for the rightmost /, then searching for string ROOT and going leftside, it finds another /.

Finally, it copies /next after the left /, before ROOT and creates ..../next\x00T...

We need at least one slash, because strlen(NULL) segfaults. The security issue is that if we don’t set left slash, it continues to the left through different chunk, for example:

In this case we copy everything after ROOT/ to the 1st chunk and overwrite the chunk metadata, so we have classic heap overflow.

To verify our concept, we attach to the final2 process as root user:

We use GOT technique, modifing write and the shellcode will be stored in our first chunk (0x804e010).

So we need to write 0x804e010 to 0x804d41c.

To check where are usable data in our buffer, we use metasploit pattern:

Our code starts at pattern offset 4. There is also modification in the first 12 bytes, we use 2 bytes instruction and skip next 10 bytes, using \xeb\x0a opcode.

After another segfault, we have in gdb:

We can see above, that we have 26*4=104 bytes for our shellcode.

Exploitation:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Net Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Net0

Converting strings to little endian integers. Solution:

Protostar Net1

Another easy challenge, we need to convert binary integers to string. Solution:

Protostar Net2

We need to add up 4 unsigned 32-bit integers. Solution:

Protostar Net3

It is easy to solve the challenge when we understand the code. For this purposes, we modified the source code to use a terminal for input or output, instead of socket.

After a few tries, we got:

Protostar Net4

This level has only the binary without description, but after disassembling we realize, that there is nothing to solve:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Heap Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Heap0

0x41346341 represents the offset 72, also 0x804a050 - 0x804a008 = 72. So we write 64B to d->name and after another 8B, there is the address of fp.

To verify our statement, we use ltrace and gdb:

We set fp to winner() symbol:

Protostar Heap1

We have four allocated chunks in memory:

After 20 bytes, we are able to change i2-name(addr), that is used by second strcpy().

We use Global Offset Table Hijacking technique:

Goal is to write the value 0x08048494 to the 0x08049774 address.

The second strcpy() takes i2-name(addr) = 0x08049774 and copies over there the argv[2] value.

Protostar Heap2

Running the binary:

This is strange, the service variable is allocated at 0x0804c018, but obviously we cannot have the following heap chucks:

There should be sizeof(struct auth) = 32+4 instead of sizeof(auth) = 4 and in our buggy code we allocated only four bytes of memory:

This is very simple Use-After-Free vulnerability. We need to write something to auth-auth, after 0x0804c028-0x0804c018 = 16 bytes.

As we can see above, we sent 15 character + newline.

Protostar Heap3

This level introduces old Doug Lea Malloc version, which is statically linked with heap3 binary.

We have three chunks at the appropriate addresses:

There are a several great article about this topic, I recommend Phrack 57/8, Phrack 57/9, Hackers Hut to explain the exploitation process in detail.

The malloc chunk could be considered as the following structure:

It is useful to download the glibc 2.2.3 source code, we are interested, how is the free() implemented:

To call vulnerable unlink(), we have two branches, consolidate backward or consolidate forward.

We want to overwrite the jump to printf/puts function in GOT table with the address of winner().

Given the bck and fwd pointers that we could set arbitrary, free() will do *(fwd+12) = bck and *(bck+8) = fwd. We use the first assignment to write to the arbitrary memory location.

Because the second assignment, we cannot simply write something to .text section (after winner+0x8), but jumping to our shellcode stored in allocated memory would be efficient.

Exploit:

To explain the logic behind our code, because size has the lowest bit set as !PREV_INUSE and p points to the beginning of our current chunk, we triggered the following part of pseudocode with the first free():

Here the address of “virtual chunk” was computed and unlinked:

However, there is another test in consolidate forward:

Here we are verifying, if the PREV_INUSE flag is set (0x43424101), so we skipped the forward consolidation:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Format Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Format0

From the output above, we can see:

Because the pattern 0x63413163 means offset 64, we could trivially pass the challenge by overflowing buffer array, because int target follows immediately (0x4c - 64 = 0xc):

This level should be done in less than 10 bytes of input, so let’s try similar approach by overflowing the buffer using format string exploitation.

Protostar Format1

We want to write something to global variable target, stored in bss section. It has fixed address:

To find the DDDD = 0x44444444 on the stack, after a few tries we have:

Protostar Format2

Protostar Format3

We need to rewrite the address at 0x080496f4 with the value 0x01025544. For this purpose we prepare simple ruby script to calculate the exact format string:

The challenge could be also solved with hellman’s libformatstr.py.

Protostar Format4

Using Global Offset Table Hijacking technique, we will try to overwrite the 0x08049724 address - jmp in exit(), with 0x080484b4 - symbol hello, at offset 4.

Correspondingly:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Stack Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Stack0

Protostar Stack1

Protostar Stack2

Protostar Stack3

We need to rewrite fp function address with the address of win().

Protostar Stack4

We use metasploit patterns (on Kali Linux) to determine the exact location of stored EIP:

Protostar Stack5

The idea is the same as in Stack4, but we need to store shellcode on stack, for example.

Stack is executable:

To have the same address in bash and gdb, we use hellman’s fixenv tool.

The address 0xbffff820 represents the buffer[] address, we store our shellcode here and jump to this address. Also we know, that return address is overwritten after position 76, from Protostar Stack4. We created our shellcode here.

The shell is executed, however it receives EOF. For this purposes, we can keep it alive with cat command:

Sometimes a more convenient solution could be storing shellcode in environment:

We do not need to use r.sh again - the EGG address could be easily calculated (albeit it’s different, because fixenv clears our environment):

Protostar Stack6

Using pattern_create.rb / pattern_offset.rb we found out that the stored return address is at offset 80.

There is a great return-to-libc writeup to explain the stack structure.

Address of system() is always the same, 0xb7ecffb0, now we need to find the /bin/sh string on the stack.

Without setreuid() call we have only euid=0, so we prepare this shell wrapper:

Protostar Stack7

The offset for return address is again 80 (0x37634136 in pattern_offset) and EAX with stored 0x804a008 value points to the beginning of our buffer, where we still can jump.

This is because strdup() allocates memory on heap and returns this address:

Instead of pointing to the allocated buffer address, it is more portable to find call eax instruction addresses in code and use one of them.

entry.title: IA-32 Linux Shellcode Basics 2
entry.content:
Starting with the ASM code that is position dependent:

The minimalistic shell could look like execve("/bin/sh", NULL, NULL). However, according documentation it’s not portable among UNIX systems:

Again, the same procedure. We need to get rid of absolute address reference and NULL bytes.

Before we dump our opcodes, we add setreuid(geteuid(), geteuid() call:

Analogously as before:

Alternatively we can obtain string reference with call instruction:

The segfault is normal and it’s because we are trying to overwrite the code segment at the line mov BYTE PTR [ebx+0x7],cl. However, our shellcode will be loaded on stack and that doesn’t mean any complication.

entry.title: IA-32 Linux Shellcode Basics 1
entry.content:
We start with the simple shellcode, that prints hello string. For this purpose, we use Kali Linux 32 bit distribution, that could be downloaded here.

Because we want to have code as simple as possible, we use tcc ansi compiler and nasm assembler.

As we can see, the string is located at 0x08049304 address. However, our code should be Position Independent (PIE) and without NULL characters.

To rewrite the code about, we need to:

  • Look up the number corresponding to the system call in /usr/include/i386-linux-gnu/asm/unistd_32.h
  • Place system call number in eax, and arguments in ebx, ecx, edx… in the order they appear in the corresponding man page
  • Execute int 0x80 to alert the kernel we want to perform a system call

Our first try:

Dumping instruction bytecode:

When we set 32b register with a small value, the compiler fills the unused space with zeros. Instead, we should use AX = 16b or AL = 8b register parts (in the case of register EAX).

Next try:

We attempt to make the code position independent pushing string to the stack:

Now it looks good, but the 0x0a could sometimes terminate the buffer prematurely, so we simply do not use this character.

Now we parse out the opcodes and validate the functionality.

If we want to store shellcode to the file:

Our next step will be to execute shell.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (16-19)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level16

There is a perl script running on port 1616, source:

The service is running with flag16 privileges:

Clearly, there is RCE vulnerability (line 14), we can check it creating an arbitrary file:

Only problem is that input is uppercased and everything after whitespace character is stripped:

We tried several other methods without success. In the later case, the shell runs, but we cannot do anything useful:

Our solution was to create uppercased file in /tmp/ and use * expansion, telling bash to find the correct directory.

Level17

According documentation it is not safe to use data from untrusted source, so pickle.loads on line 14 means RCE:

Warning The pickle module is not intended to be secure against erroneous or maliciously constructed data. Never unpickle data received from an untrusted or unauthenticated source.

Our exploit for executing remote shell:

Level18

According challenge info, there are several ways how to solve this challenge.

First thing that we tried was to use parameter -d /home/flag18/password to rewrite password file with the known output, however the strcmp() doesn’t match for the reason that we cannot insert the newline character to the end of our string.

The fclose() on line 34 is not aligned, that’s strange. We found out that this call is not used in the binary file:

We can use login function to exhaust file descriptors, because when the fopen() fails, we will be logged in. After a few tries:

We used closelog to close one used descriptor and the shell is invoked, unfortunately we need to get rid of -d parameter too, bash is recycling our argv, see execve("/bin/sh", argv, envp);.

We tried --init-file as it has the second argument some file:

Second way is to use format string exploitation, line 48 is vulnerable at notsupported() function.

For debugging, we downloaded gdb-peda:

Because the Fortify2, there was no easy way to solve it, technique from phrack #67 could be very useful.

There is also buffer overflow in setuser() function, that doesn’t seem to be exploitable.

Level19

To pass the last challenge, our process parent id should match uid 0. This could be easily achieved when the parent dies and the orphan process is adopted by init.

Exploit:

Binding shell to port 2448, binary will be called from exploit.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (11-15)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level11

According to the assignment, there should be two ways how to exploit the source below.

The fread(buf, length, 1, stdin) always returns 1 as we can read in the unix manual: fread() and fwrite() return the number of items successfully read or written (i.e., not the number of characters).

Here if(length < sizeof(buf)) { we have two ways to progress. I suppose having two solutions means calling process() from the different parts of code.

The first way is setting “Content-Length: 1”. The buffer is XORed using the simple algorithm below, this time the ‘for’ cycle runs only once.

Because the buffer with ‘A’ character is not NULL terminated and contains uninitialized data, we use the technique described here Controlling uninitialized memory with LD_PRELOAD to have more luck with terminating ‘A’.

The getflag runs, albeit there is a bug in the binary, because the new process is created using system(), so it wasn’t possible to get flag11 privileges.

The second way is to use input with the length at least 1024. The decryption routine is almost symmetric. However, in this step key -= buffer[i]; we need to substract from key the original value, so we XOR it with the key again.

Level12

The code below should be backdoored:

With io.popen we can invoke arbitrary command using several techniques. We use command substitution and two screens to gain reverse shell using bash:

Level13

The vulnerable program checks if the user does match the specific user id.

Because we know where the value 0x3e8 = 1000 is used to compare with eax, now we need only to tamper this value:

As another solution we use the PRELOAD library. We use the copy of flag13, because the restriction with invoking preload with suid binaries.

Level14

The encryption process is trivial, on each byte position, the /home/flag14/flag14 add the position index to the ascii value of the character, started by 0, see:

Now we use the reverse process to decrypt the token:

Level15

From strace output we can see that the binary is trying to link shared library from /var/tmp/flag15 directory:

We try to provide this library (in /var/tmp/flag15/libc.so.6):

There is an error, because we are linking using GLIBC_2.1.3, but in the binary, there are two symbols with GLIBC_2.0 undefined:

We provide version script to the linker, link statically and try the same thing again.

The second way how to solve the challenge is without linking libc, writing assembler code. For this purpose we used nasm assembler, everything needed for the compilation process was already on the nebula iso.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (06-10)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level06

From the assignment “The flag06 account credentials came from a legacy unix system” we conclude that the password is stored in /etc/passwd.

We store credentials to /tmp/hash.txt and use john:

Now we can log using ‘hello’ password:

Level07

The configuration file is stored in ‘/home/flag07/thttpd.conf’.

Because there is no input validation, we have RCE:

Inspired by Reverse Shell Cheat Sheet

we can create reverse shell on port 1337 via bash, using ruby to encode our payload:

In the window with nc, we got:

Level08

We can see from the output above that 0x7f represents delete keystore, so the password we are looking for is ‘backd00Rmate’

Level09

Because the flag09 binary is interpreted via php shell, there is a trivial solution:

Second way how to solve this challenge is to use PCRE pattern modifiers vulnerability in PREG_REPLACE_EVAL.

Because we cannot use quotes, we can inject something with complex (curly) syntax, that could be used for strings representation.

Here the second argument $use_me is invoked:

Actually, I have found the third solution without using $use_me parameter, but recycling $filename:

Level10

What to do is immediately clear, there is a race condition in the code, after we call access() to some file, it could be different file with the same name, which we are trying to open.

So /home/flag10/flag10 binary sends arbitrary file with access() permission to some host, port 18211.

We can test it in two screens using:

Our exploit:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (00-05)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Because it was not possible to log in via ssh, we generated the host key:

Level00

We found a suspicious file on the first line, after executing, we obtained flag.

Level01

Solution:

Level02

Solution:

Level03

There is a crontab entry that is called every couple of minutes.

Because the /tmp is mounted with nosuid option, we use home directory to store suid binary:

The file invoked by cron is here:

Our code to obtain suid shell:

After a little waiting, the suid binary is created:

Level04

We cannot read the token file, but symlink technique is sufficient:

Level05

In /home/flag05 we can find the backup file with ssh private key.

entry.title: Hackademic: RTB2
entry.content:
Image: Hackademic: RTB2

We gained the IP address 192.168.80.150 for our testing target.

Nmap output:

It seems that the port 666 is filtered by the firewall. After running nmap scan several times, we found the port to be open.

Nikto output for port 80:

The web page suggests to look for SQLi, unfortunately we were not able to find any here.

Trying hydra for bruteforce or joomscan (port 666) reveals us nothing new too.

After a little time, we found SQLi in Joomla and dumped the whole database:

Trying to crack MySQL hashes was without success.

We parse the Joomla usernames and passwords and crack using John:

Because the SQLi statements are executed by database root user, we can read or store arbitrary file to the server.

The target is Ubuntu 10.04, we can predict better the filenames in /etc:

We generate and upload the weevely shell, then upgrade to python shell over netcat:

The following credentials could be used to log in phpMyAdmin using root:

We download the Linux_Exploit_Suggester.pl and use for finding an exploit for privilege escalation:

We root the server using:

We can check the flag here. As we can see from output above, there is port-knocking mechanism using sequences 7000,8000,9000.

Finally we want to see the check.php source:

After decoding the hex characters and converting binary digits in ruby:

So the SQLi test is validated using string compare operator and it’s quite non-realistic (and unfair) to have two statements with the different case, that was the reason why we didn’t found out this firstly.

entry.title: Hackademic: RTB1
entry.content:
Image: Hackademic: RTB1

We gained the IP address 192.168.80.146 for our testing target.

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

There was SQL injection on the web page, vulnerable wordpress instance:

This will take longer and it’s not necessery to dump everything:

Some of the output:

The wordpress could be scanned using wpscan too:

“GeorgeMiller:q1w2e3” has the highest privileges (user_level 10).

We crack the hashes:

We log in using GeorgeMiller’s account and under “Manage -> Files” we upload the generated weevely shell:

We connect using weevely and found out the mysql root password:

Because our web shell doesn’t have assigned tty, we use python to create another reverse shell:

For privilege escalation, we use the following exploit:

entry.title: pWnOS: 2.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 2.0 (Pre-Release)

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

There is a SQL injection in email, we can see an error message trying to log in (filling an email field with the single quote):

Using Sqlmap we dump the whole databases:

We try to crack hashes but without success in the reasonable time:

With OS Shell functionality of Sqlmap (–os-shell), we was able to obtain shell with the web user privileges:

As we can see, MySQL daemon is running as root (=uid 0), this is also the reason, why we were able to write something with database user to /var/www (owned by www-data), that’s not common.

We can also upload weevely to the remote system and use it as the more sophisticated shell:

We found the database credentials, however they didn’t work:

That was strange, because the web application is connected. After a little more digging, we found this suspicious file:

The blog application uses the text files instead of MySQL. We were only able to locate the password file, without cracking it:

Using root / root@ISIntS we can finally log in via ssh as root:

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 3
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1.2 (#3)

DHCP client is running on the image and we got assigned this IP address:

We add to ‘/etc/hosts’:

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

After browsing the web page, we can find several vulnerabilities.

SQL injection:

Remote Code execution:

The second one has a Metasploit module that we can use (for LotusCMS):

We invoke a few commands to obtain the shell and upload weevely.

Now we can log to phpmyadmin (found for example by Nikto) with root / fuckeyou credentials:

We found the several interesting things:

In dev_accounts we have:

Using John The Ripper password cracker:

We log as loneferret user and after listing sudo -l we will see that the HT Editor could be invoked.

In editor running with the root privileges we change the /etc/passwd entry according:

We log in as dreg / Mast3r with root privileges and read the congratulation file, there is some information about alternative solutions / exploits:

entry.title: Rattus: Loophole
entry.content:
Image: Rattus: Loophole

Our objective was to find and decrypt the ‘Private.doc.enc’ file. When we boot the image, we can see the network information. With ipcalc we display the possible hosts:

We assign the last IP address from network 10.8.7.0/29:

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

Dirb output:

The most interesting file was http://10.8.7.2/garbage with these hashes:

We were able to crack each one:

Now we can log in as root via ssh, but because this was too easy, we decided to explore samba service too.

The /tmp directory is writable. We can use samba_symlink_traversal exploit in Metasploit:

We suppose we should find ‘garbage’ file this way, but the filename was too predictable for dirb.

We log in as root / albatros and crack the last user (jsummer):

Finally, we find and decrypt the file:

The file that we are looking for has the name ‘csv/Private.doc.enc-aes-256-cbc-decrypted’.

There is even an easier way to decrypt the file, looking to tskier’s home directory:
